review_title: Bureaucracy and university policies detract from potential success
pros:
-Benefits package is on par with other regional employers
- Educational opportunities and free(ish) tuition for staff and dependents
- access to cutting edge technology
cons:
- 37.5 hour work week is doggedly enforced for hourly employees, limiting earning potential and discouraging dedication to work when necessary
- University politics, bureaucracy, and red tape results in under paid employees across all departments. 
- Compensation decisions are only up to HR and the salary determination process is opaque for even managers and PIs (Primary Investigators, a.k.a. professors)
- Gross underpayment of research staff. (i.e. staff scientists with decades of experience are compensated equivalent to NIH recommend minimums for first year post doctorate researchers, technicians with multiple years of experience are payed 80% of what entry level positions pay in industry)
- experience not directly related to job posting is not considered when determining compensation 
- internal/interdepartmental transfers aren't allowed per HR equal opportunity policy, which causes confusion and frustration for applicants that have to be interviewed for a position that has already been filled by someone who already works for the university. This is counter productive to the goal of the policy 
-HR red tape 
- Athletics is paramount and everything else suffers because of it.
- Poor interdepartmental cooperation resulting in resource hording and wasteful spending
- HR policy around spousal employment/nepotism are useless and actively detrimental

But overall, there's a very top-down culture, especially for staff. If you have a problem with your manager or someone higher than you up the reporting line, HR will not help you. In my experience, you are only treated well if you drink the kool-aid of how great the school is and spout the same meaningless platitudes of the administration. There's a reason so many departments have a high turnover rate. My best advice would be to pick your department carefully, or to take a job to get your foot in the door with the intention of switching to a department/unit that is healthy and sane.

review_title: Where did the past 20 years of my life go?

cons: Horribly political in one half and zero advancement in the other. If you're a certain kind of person, however, you can connive the system to play the politics while doing very little work for decades and decades. The Ivy League tuition doesn't trickle down to the employees. If you're up for spending the rest of your days doing very little and then looking back with regret at doing just that, U of L is the place for you.

pros: Laid back culture for most support staff.  Benefits are really good if you take advantage of them.  Most departments want to see staff improve and are usually flexible with time to take classes.  Working for UofL isn't quite like having a union job, but it's pretty close.  The bureaucracy of things is a double edged sword, it helps more than it hurts though.  Most coworkers are generally pleasant.  What some may lack in ability they make up for in institutional knowledge, and both really do have their place here.  Diverse set of people throughout UofL which is pretty cool.
cons:
New COO is giving a very ambiguous, very confused vision of how he sees the future of UofL.  This matters a great deal. His fumbling on this one point creates frustration among leadership and unnecessarily frightens the rank and file. 

The culture is pretty much set.  Assimilation is not difficult but it is necessary if you want to be happy here.

job_title: Dental Clinic Associate in Louisville, KY
pros: The benefit packages are good, as long as you take advantage of them.  Tuition remission is great if you want to further your education.  And medical benefits are good as well.
cons: Management is terrible.  At least in my department, it's very much who you know and who you suck up to.  The pay scale is terrible.  Extremely low for the hourly employees.  I have actually made more money working in a factory before I even decided to go to college.  The only reason I am still employed at the University is so I can go back and get my Masters, and have most of my tuition payed for.

pros:
- great benefits (low deductible on health insurance, great PTO and retirement contribution)
- Improving work culture - President Bendapudi has made an emphasis on making UofL a great place to work.
- Tuition Remission for employee and your children - considering the cost of college today, this is an incredible value. I plan to start my MBA here next fall and it will be paid for :)
cons:
- UofL has had some struggles over the last 5-10 years from high profile leaders, which has tarnished the school's image and made some in the community unhappy with the school.
- UofL is technically an ACC school, but lags behind its peer institutions in many ways. The arrow is trending up under Bendapudi for sure, but there is still a lot of ground to be made up. The campus in particular was considered a commuter campus for many years, it's only within the last 20~ years that there has been a push to transform the school into a residential university. But there are still a lot of old buildings in disrepair, A/C that doesn't work properly, etc.

review_title: Top notch research (medical school) in a non-pretentious environment in the beautiful and affordable Louisville, KY.
pros: The Health Sciences research complex at the University of Louisville's downtown medical campus offered many opportunities to interact with researchers, medical personnel, students, and the public. Additionally, as a graduate student, I felt that I had access to any type of research equipment that I could ever need, as well as very patient and knowledgeable mentors.  I also loved the fact that the department included staff, faculty, and students from all over the world.
cons: Not a lot of teaching opportunities because the main undergraduate campus is on the other side of the city. The immediate area around the medical campus definitely has some sketchy characters, and caution must be taken if you are going to work late and walk to your vehicle several blocks away.  The shuttle service ran pretty often to the parking lots, so you could definitely feel safe during normal hours.

review_title: Depends on the area you work in...
pros: Vacation, retirement, insurance benefits, educational benefits
cons: Some areas have no  leadership whatsoever and individuals do not communicate with anyone outside their good ole boys network.  Do not be fooled by "Advavcement." nothing is advanced about it.  Those with the knowledge to improve things are pushed aside so the good ole boys can secure their positions and take care of their friends.  Great employees come and go or they push them out while the dead weight remains. The top level allows the middle to repeat the same garbage over and over instead of listening to everyone involved from the bottom up.  If there is a problem, they ask the source of that  problem, so they never hear the truth. The middle is so bogged down with their politics that they don't want it to change.  Many have never worked anywhere else and are extremely protective over keeping things as they have always known it.  Looking elsewhere before that  mentality rubs off.

review_title: University of Louisville is an OK place to work, but will not forward your career.
pros: Great Benefits, great community, great city. The campus is really nice, close to the city with good lunch options.  IT department is involved in the community with volunteer and donation programs.  The new CIO is forward thinking and may be able to improve work situations greatly.
cons: Management is very interested in putting check-marks in boxes for projects completed.  They are not really interested in moving forward or improving processes.  The workload is way more than can possibly be done in a 40 hour workweek.  This is true for all teams in IT.  We use Novell, and Novell has not been helpful in being compatible with software the rest of the world uses.  Email systems, file and print services and other services are Novell.

review_title: Great opportunity for anyone seeking a graduate level degree!!
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Louisville, KY
pros: Graduate Assistantships are a fantastic option for those interested in pursuing upper level degrees but not sure if they have the money. Covers all tuition, and only requires 20 hours of work a week. Flexible schedule. Work comes in waves, but you frequently have down time. Monthly stipend is small but more than enough to cover expenses. Basically you will get paid to get a degree that will help you in the future. Highly recommended.
cons: Sometimes you have very little to work on, and often assignments are trivial. You will feel underutilized as some professors will never be interested in your help. Mostly finding journal articles and compiling data. You have to weigh the small amount of income (but ample free time) with having a full time job (but paying your own tuition.)

pros: Pension Plan, tuition paid for employees
cons: Low salary, lack of leadership,lack of transparency, extremely secretive and political. There are some who could watch their manager pocket university funds and turn their head to keep their own job. They are just as guilty but they have seen what happens to those who speak up against it.  It takes a submissive personality to accept that.  Better to look elsewhere for an environment of strong leadership who sets the right example.  Some areas are ran  like a group of manipulative sorority sisters or fraternity brothers --  their mentality is to "remain silent and protect the guilty if you want to keep your job.". If you can live like that,  then you are a good match.

review_title: Good place to work, lots of departments with 'clickish' management
pros: Much more stress working on Health Sciences Campus versus Belknap.  Plenty of work to do in most jobs. I enjoy working with faculty members, medical staff not so much.  Lots of fun working on Belknap with all the students and activities going on.  Good pay, great benefits & free tuition for employees and spouses.  Belknap is a beautiful campus.  Quite a few job openings always posted but hard to move up.
cons: Many departments with reputations of bad management, some I have experienced personally.  Not much recourse if you want to keep your job.  Health Sciences Campus is spread out near the UofL hospital where there is higher than average crime, lots of homeless and unemployed people walking around asking for money or looking for a purse to steal.  Peoplesoft system and paperwork at UofL is a nightmare.

review_title: Quite possibly the most horrible place I have ever worked.
pros: Well it's a job that almost keeps me from starving.
cons: Nepotism, cronyism.  Want your kid to get an advanced professional degree?  Donate a bunch of money and be a volunteer faculty member.  I have worked at four other universities and have never been treated this bad anywhere.  I have had a faculty member call me white trash, ask if my pubic hair was gray and asked about my sex life with my husband.  I didn't bother documenting this because other staff have filed complaints about the same person and were told that they were the problem and needed to leave. Department chairs that are in charge and run to an assistant dean with every problem.  Faculty not showing up on schedule and taking a day off without telling anyone.  If hourly staff acted like this they'd be fired.  Poverty wages and the benefits are a joke.  Look elsewhere.

pros: Tuition Remission, Health benefits (before Obamacare), Training Opportunities. Staff Senate, Committees and generous Leave/Vacation hours.  Shelby campus had free parking.
cons: Low pay, little opportunity to move up or even lateral, office policies are old and outdated. The job duties for the position  I applied for and the job duties had when I left were not the same.  Often times you would get called for an internal job interview, only to find out the position had already been filled, but they had to have a certain number of interviews.

pros: Helpful and friendly professors and staff. A great education incorporated with the medical school. Outstanding, well published, research professors, from all types of backgrounds. A modern and up to date scientific education program. All the perks of being a University of Louisville student, i.e. free bus pass with student ID, etc. Fellowship can be awarded to pay for tuition and living expenses. Finally, Louisville is a vibrant and progressive city with a multitude of restaurants, activities, and an ever-growing outdoor culture..
cons: parking on the health sciences campus downtown is either expensive or a pain. Though updating the curriculum is necessary, the interim years can be difficult for students. A strong push for academic careers can be stifling, and the information and options of alternative careers is few and far between. (However, still accessible if one knows where to look or who to ask)

job_title: Academic Counselor Senior in Louisville, KY
pros: The faculty, staff, and students at UL were wonderful to work with during my time there.  The work environment was pleasant, and fairly fast-paced throughout the year.  Numerous opportunities to engage with colleagues across campus on committees and special projects.  The University also offered great benefits including tuition remission for employees and their spouses/dependents. Retirement plan options were plentiful.
cons: Limited opportunities for growth in the field.  Current employee salaries often lack far behind those of newer highers.

pros: The univeristy is a great place for those who are looking for flexible schedule. Benefits are great. Staff have a 7.5 hour work day.
cons: With the State of Kentucky behind the budget many have not had raises. Some are going on 4 years. In addition to no raises, they don't pay as well as you would expect in a corporate job. I estimate the university will pay professional staff about $15,000 less than their counterpart position in the corporate world. UofL rarely promotes within. If you want a promotion you will have to interview for another position available at the university otherwise you may work the next 20 years doing the same job.

pros: Varied work, could stick with people you like, could work with interesting departments or programs. I was able to work with my strengths and do work that I'm proud to have on my resume. There's formal training for teaching assistants, a very good program, though you might already be teaching once you're able to do it, which is difficult.
cons: Could get stuck in a terrible spot, assignments could be too political and not very helpful to the grad. You need to be savvy and ask around about different opportunities, even outside of your department.  I had good jobs but saw a few others run like somebody's personal assistant.

pros: There is a lot of vacation time provided (if you can take time away from the laboratory).
cons: The electronic communication used by the University is ANTIQUATED!! Email inbox size is limited to 200MB. Yes, that is correct, 200MB! The IT department is incredibly ignorant about current technologies and is not helpful for any form of network-based storage or data transfer. The benefits are  terrible and health plan is every expensive while covering very little. Most labs keep to themselves, making collaborations very difficult. Postdocs are truly treated like 3rd class citizens while technicians and lab managers are treated with respect. University hiring freeze has made it nearly impossible to find a tenure track position.

pros: Louisville is a great city to live in.  If you are a U of L (not ULP - big difference) employee you get free tuition for yourself and your dependents  although this may be changing. The retirement match is amazing!!
cons: Underpaid compared to market, no raise in over 4 years (who knows when next one will be/if any), older physicians and management still good old boy club, reduced CME funds , lack of transparency regarding your RVU value - “don’t ask because it throws up red flags”

review_title: Biochemistry and Molecular Biology PhD student
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Louisville, KY
pros: UofL is a great place to obtain an advance degree. The academic environment is wonderful. There are plenty of instruments available for use. Interaction with other faculty is great. Louisville is a great place to live and work. The cost of living is extremely low while pay is more than comparable to other graduate programs.
cons: I get absolutely no interaction with the industrial side of research - no job opportunities in Louisville for scientists except for the Univ. of Louisville.

pros: The University of Louisville is a great employer. They offer benefits and a generous vacation plan. I enjoy working with my colleagues.
cons: The University of Louisville can be a difficult place to work when bureaucracy comes into play. The school is such a huge place, that certain tasks are not as efficient as they could be.

pros: Lots of creative energy, Great resources, Lots of truly intelligent people.  A great environment of growth and knowledge.  Technology support and resources are excellent. The Delphi center is terrific for professional development and always has some new workshop running to help faculty further their educational goals.
cons: Mistakes seem to never be forgotten. Environment is fairly political as in you have to know and stay on the right side of the right people or you are ignored.

review_title: Terrible leadership, rock bottom morale, falling standards
pros: Decent benefits, including tuition remission for dependents. Attractive campus with excellent library. COL is very reasonable locally.
cons: Leadership does not communicate, annual budget cuts, corruption and fraud have been rampant. Morale is worse than low. At this moment, there is no leadership (president has resigned but resignation not yet accepted, BOT has been disbanded but there is no new board, other leaders are in acting role only). Salaries are flat, layoffs are imminent. Departments are silos in competition with each other. Staff advancement opportunities are limited to nil. Academic standards are dropping to accommodate demand for degree production regardless of student achievement.

pros: Wonderful place to work.   The University of Louisville is fair and equitable place to work and thrive.  Leadership at UofL retains and rewards talent.  I hope to be with them for years to come.
cons: They are a big university system.  That said, there are always negatives associated with being treated like you are in a system, versus being a part of a system.

review_title: Good ole boy system run amuck! School of Nursing
pros: Colleagues and working with students. That’s it but I’m required to write twenty words. Children’s books on good behaviors should be mandatory for all administrators.
cons: You better suck up and snitch to the boss if you hope to get a promotion! Regardless of experience and qualifications. EXIT INTERVIEWS SHOULD NOT BE DONE OR REQUESTED BY THE DEAN OF A PARTICULAR SCHOOL BUT SHOULD BE VIA HUMAN RESOURCES!

review_title: A great school and a great place to work.
pros: Benefits are above average.  University has many of the qualities of a larger university, and it is not spread out geographically.  Health care in Louisville is superb because of the university's medical school.
cons: Campus is not located in the nicest part of town.  Traffic is often heavy during commute hours, but there are plenty of alternate routes that avoid the interstate and have far less congestion.  Human resources department is - well - a typical human resources department (inefficient and slow).

review_title: Overall, I had good experience at UofL. I met a lot of really great people, many of whom I still keep in contact with.
job_title: Senior Research Associate in Louisville, KY
pros: They have the best retirement plan I have ever seen. I really enjoyed my coworkers and most of the staff was exemplary.  They also offer an entire week off during Christmas, that does not include your vacation days, sometimes a bit more depending on the day that Christmas fell on.
cons: Salary compensation is not very high.  Be sure to negotiate a good initial salary.

review_title: Better than other local options but still terrible pay
pros: The environment is great and the university is wonderfully full of life. The university very much has the potential to be great.
cons: The pay is downright awful. Much like many other universities, this one leverages  the "passion" of educators and researchers into paying them subpar wages. Shame on U of L and shame on the academy in general these days.

pros:
- Exciting research opportunities
- Small company feel within departments
- State of the art research facilities
- Beautiful, well-maintained campus
- Outstanding benefits. I challenge anyone to find something comparable in the private sector. Benefits included paid vacation and sick time, ability to carry up to 8 weeks of accrued vacation time from one fiscal year to the next, health insurance with a wellness program and access to university fitness facilities, 403b retirement account with a 4 to 1 match on employee contributions up to 2.5% (10% employer contribution for 2.5% employee contribution), paid maternity AND paternity leave, up to 6 hours of coursework free per semester per employee, free tuition for children of employees, almost unlimited access to university library facilities, dozens of events for employees and families throughout the year
cons:
- Compensation is lower than private sector.
- Too much middle-management/bureaucracy.
- Poor job security for employees in soft money (grant funded) positions. This was the main reason I chose to leave my position at UofL. After 7 years of work, I did not feel my job was any more secure than when I began and when a more secure private sector position became available, I took it. Hard money employees fare better with job security. Many have been there 20+ years. If interviewing for position at UofL, be sure to ask whether the position is hard or soft money. I would love to return to UofL but they would have to address the job security concern above all others for me to consider it.

review_title: Here we go again! No promo unless you suck up or threaten to leave
job_title: Associate Professor in New York, NY
pros:
Good benefits, overall
Flexibility 
I can't submit this without writing 20 words for "pros" but I don't have 20!
cons:
Workload variations in departments makes it hard to choke down when you look at salaries and workload.

Little if any  room for promotion for term faculty. WHY?

cons: there is not much infrastructure in place for graduate students in social science departments to conduct research. there are funds there, but they are under-utilized as graduate students are ill-informed of their existence and deadlines. the university could take steps to make graduate student research more of a priority, and the entire university community would benefit from it.

pros:

cons:

pros:
